 Mammals evolved from a species of reptile, which evolved from a species of amphibian, which evolved from a species of fish. And we have pretty good fossil sequences covering those gradual transitions.
 
 Possibly the most graphic illustration of this ancestry is found in the recurrent laryngeal nerve. In bony fish, this nerve takes a straightforward route from the base of the brain to its destination in the throat area. However, if you take a fish and gradually deform it into a mammal, squishing and stretching the body, limbs and internal organs but never allowing anything to 'snap' and reattach - rather like one of those puzzles made out of interwoven hoops or bits of string - you find you end up with the recurrent laryngeal nerve awkwardly looped around one of the main arteries near the heart.
 
 On this absurd detour into the chest area the nerve would pass within an inch or so of its destination - clearly we would not expect designed mammals to exhibit such a crazy feature, right?
 
 So what do you think we find when we dissect a mammal?
 
 That's right: we find the laryngeal nerve pointlessly looped around the artery near the heart, down in the chest. And this is true for every mammal. Including giraffes.

 It's a reasonable question, which has a reasonable answer.
 
 Life took billions of years to produce the first multicellular organism, but only a few million years to produce a wide variety of those multicellular organisms. Why? Because the hard part of making a multicellular organism is making a differentiable cell. Once you have a process in place for doing that, evolving modifications to it are relatively easy. When you consider how dissimilar two human beings can be, compared to how identical two bacterium of the same species are, the extra plasticity of multicellular forms is obvious, right?
 
 Ok, so what happens when 90%+ of species are wiped out is that the most adaptable, the most plastic of the survivors will diversify into new or empty niches. That's why there are so many mammals, so many rodents, so many monkeys, so many birds - and it can happen rapidly compared to the time taken to produce the progenitor species itself because squashing and stretching bits of an existing bodyplan is relatively trivial.
 
 As far as humans being 'advanced' goes, well, we're certainly extreme in one sense, whilst being comparatively rubbish in most others. Leaving that aside, there's no reason to expect humans to take an especially long time to evolve (after all, we diverged from our common ancestor with the other primates only a few million years ago). But for large-brained, dextrous, social creatures like ourselves to evolve, circumstances have to favour evolution in a particular direction. For instance, before you can have creatures like us you have to have warm-blooded organisms like mammals, because lizards and the like don't have the right metabolism to support large, expensive brains. And those mammals, starting out as they did as little shrewish creatures, have to get the opportunity to diversify, so they'll have to wait around for a major extinction event to allow their plasticity to shine. And so on. 
 
 Does that at least partly answer your question?

 Just to be completely clear, the person asking "what use is one feather?" was not being stupid. He understood the core principles of evolution - that's why he was so convinced it must be wrong - no, what led him astray was how he thought 'small changes' would manifest themselves. I mean, sprouting a feather is a small change, right?
 
 Well, no. As he went on to point out, a feather is a pretty complex structure. It's not going to form all in one go. The best evidence we have points to a gradual evolution of the skin, with horny platelets developing progressively elongated spines - most likely useful for heat retention, a bit like mammalian hairs - which as time went on became more and more barbed and complex, their branches interlocking to hold in more heat and repel water. Their use in flight almost certainly came very late in the day: feathered dinosaurs diversifying into birds rather like mammals diversified into bats.
 
side note: Every time I look at a bird, I can't help but feel that something is missing - hands. 

 Good point. There's no good reason why at least some birds couldn't have been designed with hands - but there is every reason, from an evolutionary perspective, to predict that we will never ever find a species of bird with hands as well as wings, because birds' wings are their hands (just like bats' wings are theirs). Evolution works by tweaking and distorting what's already there, and a bird sprouting an extra pair of fully formed limbs doesn't count as 'tweaking' :)
 
 Now, I'm sure that statement is ringing all kinds of alarm bells, right? If evolution can't be expected to cause a creature to sprout fully-formed extra limbs, how did creatures get their limbs in the first place?
 
 The key here is to understand that the basic body plans formed very, very early on, when the differentiation of creatures' bodies was much simpler. Wiggly worms with wiggly legs, so to speak. Around about the Cambrian a riot of bodyshapes burst onto the scene, most of them dying out leaving only a few to inherit the earth in various descendant forms, with those crude wiggly appendages refined into fins, limbs, feet, hands...
 
 The wonderful thing about evolution, to me, is that it means you can look at any animal and say "I know why you are the way you are, rather than something else." Nothing is arbitrary. The giraffe's neck has the same number of bones as yours for a reason. Animals with four legs have four legs for a reason. We suffer from scurvy if we don't eat fruit for a reason (at some point our distant ancestors - long before we diverged from the other apes - lived on such a fruit-rich diet that the loss of a critical Vit-C manufacturing gene went unnoticed by natural selection, and now we're stuck that way). The idea that evolution somehow diminishes the wonder of the natural world strikes me as simultaneously ludicrous and deeply sad.

 Have you read Origin of Species? The language is a bit old-fashioned but I found it very illuminating, particularly when it comes to thinking about the forces driving diversification. The essential point is that diversification maximizes the biological potential of any given habitat. For instance, X amount of savanna can only support Y buffalo before they start to starve, but the same savanna can also support Z gazelle, because gazelle can eat shorter grass. Not to mention giraffe which can feed off the trees.
 
 In other words, it might not be a question of dinosaurs needing to change into birds, but of those dinosaurs which became more bird-like being able to exploit an otherwise empty ecological niche, allowing them to flourish alongside and diverge from their cousins.
